Fields.DialogueText: Please, gentlemen, do be careful with that crate! It's not... entirely safe.
No offense, ma'am, but we kinda figured that out from the growling noises.
Hm. I suppose she's gotten her muzzle off again.
Dare I ask what you're bringing onto my ship, Commander?
Oh, wild animal. Terribly ferocious. Best not to think about it too much, I find.
I really am terribly grateful for the hospitality, Captain. I know you weren't given much notice of my arrival.

Fields.MenuText: Given the war I've been having, too much advance notice of anything would only confuse me.
No. I wasn't.
All I was really given was a vague promise that you'd explain what's going on once you were settled in.

Fields.DialogueText: That's the spirit!
... Okay.
Don't worry, Captain. All will be revealed in time.
That's gratifying.
Possibly also untrue, but let's not dwell on it just now.
I do thank you for finding rooms for my bevy of boffins as well. I realise that arranging for privacy for a research team is challenging, under the circumstances-
That's one word for it, yes.
But we feel - and the League agrees - that our little project is best served by a particular degree of discretion.
You're Royal Navy?
Only under grave duress. On both sides, really.
Yes, that's an excellent question. By the way, Captain, I do hope we're making good time?
... We are. I take it we're on an intercept course?
Very good, Captain! You're really very clever.
Am I permitted to ask what we hope to intercept?
Or, let me rephrase: what are the Morganas up to now?
If our suspicions are correct, I'm afraid it's not so much a matter of "what" as of "who."
And you're assigned to HMS Pembroke VII.
I suppose I am.
Which is... what, exactly?
You may be about to see what I mean.
@BATTLE
Captain! I think you're needed on the bridge!
I need an explanation. Now.
We can start with the mystery Morgana - and what was wrong with it.
Wrong? Interesting. Captain, you have much more experience than I do seeing these things in battle - can you tell me what was different?
Actually, wait - would you mind clearing the deck, please? This should be done in relative privacy, and I don't think I should be too far away from the crate just now.
*GROAN*
... I was really hoping the sedatives would last longer.
Give us some space, people!
Now. What are we dealing with?
You tell me. That ship was different from your normal Morgana how, exactly?

Fields.MenuText: Apart from being totally new to me?
No. My ship, my questions.
It's like... it wasn't totally in focus. And its destruction was more thorough than I usually see.

Fields.DialogueText: That's a part of it, obviously.
Frustrating... but fair.
And the Morgana herself hardly moved, if she was there at all.
We don't think she was fully awake yet.
We don't even think she was fully *here* yet. The First Wave Morganas are still trying to bring her over.
... How about you start from the beginning?
No. Regretfully. My boffins and I need to get out to where that ship was, and we need to do it immediately - this is the most important mission you have going right now, Captain.
Explanations can wait.
*CRASH*
... What the hell is in that thing?
Honestly?
Please.
Evil teddy bear.
*GNASH GNASH GNASH*
In the custody of His Majesty's government, I'm afraid.

Fields.MenuText: ... Yeah, fair enough.
Nope. I'm confiscating it until I know what the hell is going on.

Fields.DialogueText: *CRUNCH CRUNCH*
*CRUNCH CRUNCH*
If you insist. The boffins and I were either going to call her Belphegor or Blinky. I have positive associations with both.
I'm fairly certain that's the sound she makes as she gnaws through steel manacles, if you're curious.
"She?"
The boffins and I are either going to call her Belphegor or Blinky. I have positive associations with both.
... I'm just going to get the ship where you need it now.
Yes. Don't ask how we know. It was quite traumatic for everyone involved.
I'm fairly certain that's the sound she makes as she gnaws through steel manacles, if you're curious.
... You've been saying "she" and "her."
Yes. Don't ask how we know. It was quite traumatic for everyone involved.
She's already talking. Interesting.
And her taunts?
I wouldn't read too much into them. It seems almost a like a reflex - I've heard that kind of pre-battle garbage from Morganas that otherwise couldn't do more than scream.
Now. Your turn.
Thank you for seeing me, Captain. I know it's long overdue, but...
But you've been working hard, I know. Given the noises from your workshop area, I'd honestly be unprepared to bet that any of you have slept at all in the last few days.
Oh, it hasn't been so bad.
And I'm grateful to your crew for taking dear Blinky off our hands. They've done a remarkable job domesticating her.
OH, ****! SHOOT IT! SHOOT IT! IT'S GOING FOR MY ****ING EYES!
PLAY DEAD! YOU'RE SUPPOSED TO PLAY DEAD!
Ah, the carefree sounds of springtime.

Fields.MenuText: It's not actually spring.
Uh-huh.
Can somebody send our Belle out to pacify the teddy bear, please?

Fields.DialogueText: So, I take it that thing has something to do with our new visitor.
Indeed. At any rate, from what we can tell, this is a rare case of a Morgana who travels with... well, one hesitates to call it a crew. Mascots that reflect her particular mania, perhaps.
But not under her control.
No, oddly. She - Blinky, that is - seems quite taken with your own Belle, and there's no sign of mind control as we're coming to understand it.
OH SWEET ****ING MOTHER OF **** IT'S IN MY ****ING HAIR!
GOD! GOD! PLEASE DON'T MAKE ME WATCH THIS!
Do you mind if I close the hatch?
Please do. Then tell me what you know.
Know? Very little. But this is what we suppose.
The Morganas you know were the tip of the spear. There have been documented sightings of others, shimmering like mirages and then vanishing.
Until recently, they've been unable to fight - in fact, they've seemed unaware of their surroundings, so far as anyone can tell.
But now that's changing.
Yes. We believe that they're leaving parts of themselves behind when they do appear - if you don't mind the metaphor, anchors in our world.
Their colleagues from the First Wave gather these fragments and amplify their unusual properties, bringing the Second Wave closer and closer to fully manifesting.
Huh. And you base this on what, exactly? Observation?
I know Morganas better than most, and I haven't seen widespread evidence of them collecting parts or conducting unusual experiments. By Morgana standards, anyway.
You think we're wrong?
No. I think you're more confident than you ought to be, which probably means you have a source of intelligence I don't.
... I like you. I can see you're going to be terribly inconvenient in any number of ways, but I like you.

Fields.MenuText: Thank you.
Great.
So?

Fields.DialogueText: You know more than most about the very start of the war, of course. Schleswig-Holstein's first shot, the appearance of the Morganas...
Yeah.
What you may not know is that, at around four o'clock in the morning of September 2, Faroe Island time, the world had its first documented case of a major battle between two Morgana groups.
The larger force was comprised of Vanities and Delusions - big girls, but denied use of their bombers. That made a difference.
The other group was two ships. A colleague of mine with a taste for opera has code-named them "Siegmund" and "Sieglinde."
The details are sketchy, even from direct witnesses, but it seems clear that Siegmund gave her life so that Sieglinde - though badly damaged - could escape the attack.
Sieglinde was mortally wounded, but she kept running for weeks - sounding radio messages as she ran to attract human sailors so she could impart what information she had to share.
... Hope.
Yes, that too, I should think.
Siegmund... well, she died a lot sooner. But the Morganas who killed her didn't do a very good job of cleaning up the mess she left, and bits of our girl found their way to Vágafjørður.
I'm sure I said that badly, by the way. I do apologize.
But that's where my colleagues and I come in. You could say that as Sieglinde called to you, Siegmund called to *us*. We've been studying what she left behind.
We knew the Second Wave was coming - and our investigations helped us secure dear Blinky - but we don't have the means to engage these new ships as they appear. *You* do.

Fields.MenuText: Do you have any idea what's coming? Names, specifics?

Fields.DialogueText: No. As I said before, we have a little bit of the how, but not the who.

Fields.MenuText: Great. Any ideas on how to stop reinforcements from coming?

Fields.DialogueText: No. That's what we hope to learn.

Fields.MenuText: And I'm just hearing about all this now?

Fields.DialogueText: Yes. You're welcome, by the way.
Would this be a good time to ask if you could bring on a new crew member for me? Some of my colleagues are looking for... an unusual skill set. I don't have the budget, but-

Fields.MenuText: Don't push your luck.
Sure. I can use all the unusual skill sets I can get.

Fields.DialogueText: Just thought I'd ask.
Very forward-thinking of you, Captain.
Now, if you don't mind, I should be getting back to our little headquarters before my colleagues set any fires they can't contain.
Wait.
Captain?
I'm curious. What was your "Siegmund's" name?
Oh, I have no idea. There wasn't enough left of her to say.
... Don't take this the wrong way, but I don't know if I believe you.
*ALARM*
So ominous.
@BATTLE
Mm-hm. And there's at least one more in captivity elsewhere - sailors occasionally spot them swimming around. She seems to be careless with them.

Fields.MenuText: I can't say I blame her.
... I can't believe I'm saying this, but can you get us that other bear too?

Fields.DialogueText: Really?
If it's a potential source of information, I'd say the benefits are worth the screaming mortal terror.
*raised eyebrow*
No, seriously, I think it's worth the risk.
OW! OW! OW!
That's all the photos that are worth anything, Captain. We got them developed in record time.
I appreciate that you're sharing them. You lot in the boffin squad sometimes keep more secrets than I'd like.
Oh, I'm not really one of them, Captain. They hired me at the last minute when they found out I could get my hands on a plane, but... I mean, it's not a permanent thing.
I wish it was, to be honest. It's good to feel like I'm doing my bit.
Hang on. This is actually a photo of her deck? The mystery Morgana?
Um... yeah. It was weird - she let me get really close, and the AA guns never did anything.  Though there were these little... monkey-things, maybe? Little guys crawling all over the place, anyway.
Teddy bears.
Oh, God. Like that one that's stalking Midshipman Delagardie?
Eye. One eye. One eye in the dark. It sees everything.
Never mind that. This deck photo - that's actually her, isn't it? The Morgana herself, lying down?
I think so, Captain. I don't know who else it would be.
She looks awfully young. For a demon lady.
Or a cursed Valkyrie.
Captain?
Sorry. I've spent the last week reading up on operas to try to figure out some references - it's getting hard to shake off.
The captain's life is a complicated one, I guess.
Seems that way sometimes.
You know, the fleet could use another good scout. Any chance you'd want to stay on?
Captain, that's... yes! Yes, thank you!
I'll pull the appropriate strings. And thank *you*.
Dismissed.
Let's get to action stations, people! The enemy's close!
@BATTLE
That's three for three, Commander. I don't suppose you'd care to tell me we're on the verge of banishing her before she manifests for real.
No. But on a more positive note, we're tracking some really fascinating fluctuations in sea temperature around the latest wreckage.
I'm looking forward to the inevitable heavily-redacted report.
Changing topics - I wanted to talk to you about those Morgana photos. I can't help but notice that they've gone missing.
Sorry, sorry. Urgent need and all that. And at least you got the negatives carefully hidden away somewhere.
I hope you've got them safe from Blinky, mind you. She seems eager to tear them up. You know she was trying to help target the mystery Morgana in the battle?
I think she just likes the guns.
They *do* seem like very nice guns, Captain. You should be very proud.
Uh-huh. About the photos - any insights you'd care to offer?
Her pajamas don't look very warm.
I was hoping for ideas on a name. Or two.
Does it matter?
I don't know how well you know Belles, Commander - but, yes, names can matter. Quite a bit.
But Belles and Morganas are different, yes? Fundamentally different, total opposites, all that.
And, you know, it seems like they're all a little bit telepathic, if you believe in that kind of thing. So maybe it's not the names that matter - maybe they react to what *we* think about the names.

Fields.MenuText: Is this an experiment? Are you not sharing information to see if my not knowing things influences enemy development?
You're not telling me anything new, Commander.
Trust me, if they were really telepathic, I'd be super-dead by now.

Fields.DialogueText: The Belles or the Morganas?
Probably both.
I say it again, Captain. I *do* like you.
Hrm.
What would *you* call her? Based on what you've seen so far.
A sign that the war's getting away from us, Commander.
There's also a toy you might want to play with. If you're willing to sign off on the risk.
If it's a new type of ravenous stuffed animal-
It's an 80cm gun, intact. Morgana make. My team's prepared to sign off on it as being utterly almost maybe combat safe and ready for field experimentation.

Fields.MenuText: ... That's a terrible idea.

Fields.DialogueText: Wars are run on terrible ideas, Captain. Gifted officers make them work.
Or not.
Your loss!

Fields.MenuText: I want a Belle to sign off on it.

Fields.DialogueText: I'm excited to see how it works out!
It's worth a shot. Thank you.
Already done. The lady of the ship sees no danger of attempted mind control or other Morgana shenanigans. It's training the crew on use and maintenance that could be a hassle.
@BATTLE
*cough*
I think we've gotten to where you want us to be.
Don't take this the wrong way, Captain - but I was under the impression that the Belles could keep the Morganas' mist at bay.
Nobody's died from it. I think that counts.
But...
No, you're right. I haven't seen anything this bad since the start of the war.
And the Belles know Morganas are all around us, apparently, but they can't get a lock.
I hope you're getting good data...

Fields.MenuText: I know I am.
... because we're not staying long.
... because this feels like the most dangerous situation I've put my crew into since this whole mess started.

Fields.DialogueText: That's the *cough* spirit.
I'm not sure that just turning around is much of an option, Captain.
I'm *cough* proud to be a part of it, Captain.
*GRRRRRRRRR*
She's hiding behind you? That's adorable.
She's gnawing on my calf.
*THUNDER*
Just five more minutes...
Oh, hell.
You object to the timing?
That's a new voice, Commander. That's our new Morgana.
Ah. She's waking up.
Or coming through. Or shambling toward Bethlehem to be born. Whatever.
Our broadcast range in extreme Morgana conditions is usually minimal, but...
This is the First Captain of the Neutrality Fleet, speaking on behalf of the League of Nations.

Fields.MenuText: I don't want us to be enemies - not if we don't have to be.
I strongly recommend you just turn around and go back to where you came from.
We're ready when you are, lady. Come out and say hello.

Fields.DialogueText: *YAWN*
... I was expecting something a little bit more dramatic.
*THUNDER*
(Electrical lights flicker - one overhead bulb explodes)
Fine, fine. I'm coming! I can't believe you guys haven't won this yet.
... Who are we killing this time, anyway?
Captain! We have visual contact!
Oh. I see. It's Acedia.
What?
Really? I just got here and I'm already being harassed by the locals? Ugh. You guys suck.
Bears, make this go away, okay? Shoot the noisy one first.
*COUGH* Get the fires out and get us into position at the debris! Time's of the essence, people!
I appreciate the sentiment, Captain - but I think we're just about done.
Don't get me wrong - I'm always hungry for more data. But the temperature spikes are normalizing, the strange electromagnetic pulses seem to have stopped-
I noticed the compass wasn't spinning anymore.
I think the deed is done. Sloth is fully here now - and our real priority is to get my boffins safely onto dry land so we can start figuring out what to do the next time this happens.
Okay, we'll make sure that happens. But right now you're going to tell me about "Acedia."
I am?
Commander, I've been restrained about this, but I *do* outrank you.
On paper, yes.
Anyway, there's nothing to tell. The boffins and I have spent ages brainstorming horrible things that might serve as Morgana names - the Seven Deadly Sins were always obvious.
Yes. Acedia is Sloth, and I think Sloth is *her*. Dr. Pfohl actually had a three-quid bet going that one of them would appear before the year was out.
Uh-huh. So you were just thinking of the Seven Deadlies anyway, and it just clicked when you saw her in action.
It's not that you saw something in that light show before she fully manifested that the rest of us didn't.
I'm sure your eyes are just as good as mine, Captain.
Now, if you'll excuse me, I need to get the divers ready for one last survey. Sloth is our enemy in more ways than one!
... Dismissed.

Fields.MenuText: Somebody get me a preliminary damage report, please.
But if you catch any more of those bears out there, we're keeping them!

Fields.DialogueText: You need the company, don't you, buddy?
*GRRRRRR*
Truer words were never spoken.
*YAWN*
Ah. Acedia is... Sloth?
But she's doing it affectionately, or your leg would be clean off by now.
Thank you for that.
I've seen it happen.
Please stop.
You had one job, Vanity!
Never mind. Be ready to engage.
Unknown vessel, this is the best chance you're going to get. Stand down and talk to us about-
